Award.AwardTitle: A Workshop to Finalize the Planning for a National Pilot of an AP in Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides support for A Workshop to Finalize the Planning for a National Pilot of an AP in Engineering, to be held at the University of Maryland College Park (UMD) in the Fall of 2017. The three goals of the workshop are to: 1) Review and revise the Draft Curriculum Framework for the AP in Engineering. 2) Define the Role Organizations Play in the Pilot. 3) Development of Training Objectives for the Pilot Teachers.

This workshop will bring together approximately 36 participants from the following sectors within the education and engineering enterprises: 1) Deans from Schools and Colleges of Engineering; 2) College Board; 3) K-12 STEM teachers and district level leadership; 4) community college and four-year faculties; 5) consulting, technology, and manufacturing industries dependent upon engineering talent; 6) informal education programs; 7) policy-makers; and 8) public and private funders. The participants would convene to: 1) review and revise the Draft Curriculum Framework for the AP in Engineering; 2) plan the criteria and recruitment of high schools to participate in the pilot; 3) define the role organizations would play in a pilot of the AP in Engineering; 4) development of a professional development framework for the pilot teachers; and 5) discussion of the role of a Learning Management System (LMS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering, unlike many of sciences (e.g., biology, physics) or computer science or mathematics does not have:

1. A standardized Engineering pathway for pre-college students to earn a widely accepted, transferable, Introduction to Engineering credit, through either a test and / or a projectbased experience; or

2. Professional development programs that uniformly train secondary school teachers to instruct and assess Introductory to Engineering curricula in high schools.

The intent of the Workshop was to lay the foundation for a high school curriculum based on engineering principles, processes and skills aligned to the broad range of introductory engineering courses. The porposed course would cultivate student's understandings of engineering principles and practices through hands on, project based learning activities, as they explore the following topics: 1) engineering habits of mind; 2) system design thinking; 3) and the basic principles, analyses and practices of engineering.

Students would learn about the engineer’s responsibilities to society, including: economic impact, ethical considerations and political constraints while generating engineering solutions to problems. This course would include a comprehensive survey of engineering disciplines and how to address specific societal issues, including the National Academy of Engineering grand challenges (energy, health care, environment, security, and quality of life).

Prerequisites: Students would have successfully completed high school courses mathematics including algebra, geometry, trigonometry, and be taking pre-calculus concurrently. Students would have taken high school courses in biology, chemistry and be taking physics concurrently.

Engineering Course Content: The course is based on three Big Ideas, which encompass core engineering principles, theories, tools, and processes that cut across disciplines of engineering and provide a broad way of thinking about the field of engineering: practices and impact on society.

Engineering Outcomes and Practice: Students would gain an understanding of the field of engineering and its practices to formulate and solve problems. Students will use concepts and principles of engineering design, and analysis to refine solutions to problems. Focusing on these disciplinary practices enables teachers to use engineering habits of mind and design thinking and processes to promote a more engaging and rigorous experience for Engineering students.

Such practices would require that students to: 1) use representations and mathematical models to formulate, predict, and solve engineering problems; 2) perform unit conversion, estimation, approximations, and think critically about engineering problems; 3) engage in engineering design thinking to guide iterative solutions to problems within the contexts of the course; 4) use techniques, skills and modern engineering tools necessary for engineering practice; and 5) communicate and relate knowledge across various scales, concepts, andrepresentations in and across domains.
